" For 2nd press, and 3rd press actions: 700 millisecond
For >4th press: 3 second (big delay allowed here, so you can fast-forward the song comfortably.)
This just for information. You can't change anything here. "

"In a queue-tab, whenever you want to find which song is currently playing in the selected queue, just tap on the song counter. (Song counter looks something like this: Y/z where Y is position of current song in queue of total z songs).
Swipe songs to right by holding them with 2-bars given at left to remove it form queue."

"Mplayer uses the native media decoders that comes with your device, so as long as a audio format is supported by your device, it is supported by Mplayer. See Supported Formats. (Can vary with device model) "

" No.Mplayer is 100% OFFLINE app. It doesn't even transmit usage statistics and other reports.
In fact, technically it can not use internet at all. Because we (intentionally) didn't put Internet permission in it. Without 'Internet Permission' (also known as 'Full network access permission'), No android app can use internet. This is a fact.
To confirm this you can check Mplayer's 'app info' > 'Permission' > 'All Permissions'. Or Go to the PlayStore-page of Mplayer and check 'permission details' at the bottom the page. You will not find any network related permissions there."

"Mu uses android system's AudioFX components to manipulate the audio. If manufacturer of your device has altered these components, and haven't followed AOSP's guideline, then Equalizer may not work.
If Mplayer Equalizer is not working. You can try System Equalizer if it is supported by your device. To try it go to 'Mplayer'->'Settings'->'Audio'->'Equalizer to use'."

" You can have maximum 20 Queues.
Remember, too many queues, each with too many songs, can reduce performance, and increase app launch time and shutdown time. So it is recommended that you remove old queues if they are not required any more.
If name of a queue is \"All songs\" or \"Folder123\" or \"Recently added songs\" or \"AlbumXYZ\" it doesn't become actual \"All songs\" or \"Folder123\" or \"Recently added songs\" or \"AlbumXYZ\". It just has same name. You can rename it to anything. After creating a queue, when you add some new songs to your library, they will not appear in any queue. To see actual and updating lists of songs go to the their respective tabs. i.e For actual \"AlbumXYZ\" go to Albums' tab (not in queue named AlbumXYZ), for actual \"Folder123\" go to Folders' tab and for \"All songs\", and \"Recently added songs\" go to Playlists' tab, and likewise.
Name of a queue must be unique among all other queues.
No duplicate songs is allowed in a queue."
" + Contribute at Github Mplayer Github Repo. + By telling your friends about this amazing app. + By liking our page on Facebook and following us on Twitter and Instagram. "

"Mplayer is 100% free. We don't show ads. We don't collect/sell users's private data. So, in terms of money, we earn nothing from Mplayer. However we do earn lots of blessings and good wishes from Music lovers all around the world."

" Short answer: Watch this video Long but Proper Answer: Xiaomi's MIUI ROMs have very aggressive Memory management (RAM management). While multitasking MIUI keeps killing background apps(=App which are not visible on screen) in order to keep more and more RAM free. Most of the times this strategy is unnecessary. Moreover Stock android's Memory management is really good. It is reliable and perfect. But still MIUI uses its own Memory management. Decision made by MIUI for \"Which app to be killed first\" is sometimes poor. For these reasons when you are listing music in background, while using other apps, MIUI kills Musicolet. Solution? Because it is a well known problem of MIUI, there are many discussions are there on many forums on the internet. Some users have found ways to tweak MIUI's behaviour by changing some settings from developer options. Here is a Video with step by step guide: https://youtu.be/J9-8Ct0n6c0 "
" Features which is available today for free will remain free forever."

" Shuffle mode doesn't let you predict next song until you actually play next song. 'Play after current song' option will also not work when shuffle mode is on.
An alternative to shuffle mode is Randomize. Keep shuffle mode off -> go to queue-tab -> Click on sort icon -> Select randomize. It will randomize the songs in the currently selected queue (a kind of shuffle), and now you can see the new random arrangement of songs, and can know which song will be played next."

Queue is a temporary list of songs which decides the order of songs in which they are played. You can find queues in 1st tab. You can change the order of song in a queue, by simple dragging it from 2-bars given at left side.

" Mplayer is the ONLY android music player which supports multiple queues.
Benefits of Multiple-Queues: 1. You can prepare more than one queues while listening songs from some another queue.
2. Suppose you have prepared a nice queue, and you don't have multiple-queues feature (i.e. if you can have just 1 queue like other music apps) and while exploring your library you accidentally clicked on a song from a playlist/albums/search/etc. Then with just 1 queue, either your old queue with replaced with new list of songs (which happens with most of the other music apps) or all songs of that playlist/album/etc will be added to your queue. And your nicely prepared queue will be ruined. With Mplayer's multiple queues it never happens. In such a scenario Mplayer will create a new queue, and your old queue will be untouched.
3. Mplayer even remembers currently playing songs of each queue.
You can even give temporary names to every queues, and rename any queue anytime. You can also save any queue as playlist."

" \"Whenever an android app is installed on SD card or moved to SD card. Some functionality of the app including Widgets became disabled.\" This rule applies for android apps including Mplayer. So if you want to use widgets, you should keep Mplayer app on internal storage not on SD card. You may ask: I didn't installed it on SD card. It automatically installed on SD card. Answer: We (the app developers) have just 2 choices: Allow app to be installed on SD card or Not. As many users (having devices with low internal storage) were asking for this features, we allowed the app to be installed on SD card. But 'Where an app will be installed?' is decided by Android system. We don't have any control on it. How to move an app to Internal storage? Answer: (a) Go to your device Settings > Applications (or Apps) (on some device it may be in Advance settings) > Find 'Mplayer' and tap on it > Find and click button labeled 'Move to internal storage' or (b) Google \"How to move app to Internal storage in [YOUR DEVICE NAME HERE]\" "

"Go to 'Mplayer' -> 'settings' -> 'Arrange tabs'. If there you can't find genre tab there, then sadly genres is not supported in your device. Some old versions of android have many bugs with genre in the mediastore db. As Mplayer is depended on it, Genres is not possible on those devices."
" If the song has corrupted ID3 tags, or doesn't allow ID3 tags to be written on it. Or have some other issues, then tags of such song can't be edited."

" Make sure you are not finding newly added song in queues in queue-tab(1st tab). Find them in any other tabs. Because queues are completely different things from playlists.
Also make sure: The folder in which your songs are or any of its parent folders…
1) …is not added in the list of excluded folders(see Mplayer>settings>'song library'>'exclude folders')
2) …is not a hidden folder and its name does not start with .(dot)
3) …is not a private folder of any app
4) …does not contain a file named '.nomedia' (.nomedia files are usually hidden in FileManagers)

If you still can't find your songs, read this:

Mplayer does a quick scan for the new songs on every start. For fast and battery efficient scanning, it uses Android's MediaStorage framework. In Android MediaStorage framework is powerful mechanism for querying and keeping record of existing files in internal and external storage. Many apps including Gallery depends on it. But, Sometimes the apps (like file manager, browsers, file sharing apps etc. from which have downloaded/copied/moved new songs) don't notify Android MediaStorage framework about the recent changes they made. So the MediaStorage will be unaware about those changes. This is a common reason for not finding newly added songs in Mplayer. Solution: (1) Do a force rescan. (Go to Mplayer Settings > Song library > Force to rescan) or (2) Restart your device. After it restarted and everything is loaded completely, then wait for another 2-3 minutes, then open Mplayer and try to find your songs. "

" Mplayer is one of the rarest apps which don't have Internet permission (aka 'Full Network Access Permission'). In order to make Mplayer with minimum permission we intentionally didn't put that permission in the app. Without internet permission an Android app can't send/receive any data to/from internet. So the features (like auto-fetching lyrics) which requires internet are not possible. "

" Mplayer is one of the rarest apps which don't have Internet permission (aka 'Full Network Access Permission'). In order to make Mplayer with minimum permission we intentionally didn't put that permission in the app. Without internet permission an Android app can't send/receive any data to/from internet. So the features (like auto-fetching album-art) which requires internet are not possible. "
Mplayer is closed because of sleep timer. :)
Mplayer - A LightWeight music player with simple design, yet with tons of features. The only android music player with Multiple queues.
App really need your permission in order to work!

"Some manufacturers are putting their own layers of codes on stock android, such devices handle the earphone's button by its own and don't allow an app to intercept. So device just tell Mplayer to play next/previous song. But never tell that earphone's button is pressed. We can't do anything about it."

Songs and audio clips smaller than this duration will be excluded from scanning.
Songs in folders listed below will not be scanned. Songs in the sub-folders of these folders will also not be scanned.
Keeping these both values empty or 0:0 will not exclude any file.

" Does Mplayer scan new songs automatically? Yes. Mplayer does a quick scan for the new songs on every start. Then why force-rescan is needed? For fast and battery efficient scanning, Mplayer uses Android's MediaStorage framework. In Android MediaStorage framework is powerful mechanism for querying and keeping record of existing files in internal and external storage. Many apps including Gallery depends on it. But, Sometimes the apps (like file manager, browsers, file sharing apps etc. from which have downloaded/copied/moved new songs) don't notify Android MediaStorage framework about the recent changes they made. So the MediaStorage will be unaware about those changes. This is a common reason for not finding newly added songs in Mplayer. If other apps cooperate and follow MediaStorage's Guidelines correctly, then you won't need to use force-scan. Anyway, The Rescan-Button given below will force Android's MediaStorage framework to scan songs inside selected folder and its subfolder; so Android and then Mplayer can find newly added songs. "

"<small>Create a copy of Mplayer's private playlists and export them publicly. So later you can import songs from those exported backups. Existing exported playlist-backup with same name, will be replaced with newer one.</small>"

" Mplayer is developed in English. Unfortunately we don't understand your language. :(

App is translated in this language by our users.

We don't take responsibility for correctness of translation. While communicating with us (via email, playstore and any other platform) please use English if possible.

If you find some wrong translations, or want to improve the quality of current translation, you can help us. For that, Go to 'Help and info' menu, then select 'Help us in translation'. Thanks for your support. "

In android, notifications are made with RemoteViews. An app creates RemoteViews and passes them to systemUI. After that they are rendered and managed by SystemUI. ROM can make its own changes on them. So these customizations may not work in some devices or in some ROMs.
In some devices, these customizations may not work. Click here to read the reason.

" Still not finding your songs?
Make sure you are not finding newly added song in queues in queue-tab. Find them in any other tabs. Because queues are completely different things from playlists.

Also Make sure: The folder in which your songs are or any of its parent folders…

1) …is not added in the list of excluded folders(see Mplayer>settings>'song library'>'exclude folders')

2) …is not a hidden folder and its name does not start with .(dot)

3) …is not a private folder of any app

4) …does not contain a file named '.nomedia' (.nomedia files are usually hidden in FileManagers)

After resolving these issues do a rescan. "
"Do a rescan on the required folder by tapping button given above. After that if you still don't find your songs, then click here."

" You should only use this feature if you have edited metadata(ID3 tags) of songs outside Mplayer (Either by using other apps or a PC) and you are not seeing those changes in Mplayer.

If you need to use this feature, then please read this warning. You may ignore this warning if you are sure that the songs whose tags you want to reload from storage are using standard (internationally accepted) character encoding for tags.

Mplayer depends on Android's MediaStorage framework to read metadata tags. But after editing the tags of some songs, MediaStorage may fail to detect the correct encoding. If MediaStorage detects incorrect Character Encoding of songs then tags may be unreadable. However, this rarely happens, if creators of song used non-standard encoding (encoding which is not internationally excepted) for tags. If this happens, it will not be Mplayer's fault and don't blame us; We have warned you. "

" You may ignore this warning if you are sure that the songs whose tags you want to edit are using standard (internationally accepted) character encoding for tags.

Mplayer depends on Android's MediaStorage framework to read metadata tags. But after editing the tags of some songs, MediaStorage may fail to detect the correct encoding. If MediaStorage detects incorrect Character Encoding of songs then tags may be unreadable. However, this rarely happens, if creators of song used non-standard encoding (encoding which is not internationally excepted) for tags. If this happens, it will not be Mplayer's fault and don't blame us; We have warned you. "
